_link.title: I can explain how the strong nuclear force holds the nucleus together

toLevel2.question: What type of force is the strong nuclear force?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong nuclear force is an attractive force that pulls nucleons (protons and neutrons) together, holding the nucleus intact.

distractorExplanations.Repulsive: A repulsive force would push nucleons apart. The strong force attracts them.
distractorExplanations.Neutral: The strong force is definitely attractive, not neutral.
distractorExplanations.Variable: The strong force is always attractive between nucleons.

toLevel2.question: Between which particles does the strong nuclear force act?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force acts between all nucleons: proton-proton, neutron-neutron, and proton-neutron.

distractorExplanations.Only protons: The strong force also acts on neutrons.
distractorExplanations.Only neutrons: The strong force also acts on protons.
distractorExplanations.Protons and electrons: Electrons are outside the nucleus and don't experience the strong force.

toLevel2.question: Compared to the electrostatic force, how strong is the strong nuclear force?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: At nuclear distances, the strong force is approximately 100 times stronger than the electrostatic force.

distractorExplanations.About the same strength: The strong force is significantly stronger at nuclear distances.
distractorExplanations.About 100 times weaker: The strong force is stronger, not weaker, than electrostatic force at nuclear distances.
distractorExplanations.Infinitely stronger: While much stronger, it is about 100 times stronger, not infinite.

toLevel2.question: Over what distance does the strong nuclear force act?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force only acts over very short distances, about 10⁻¹⁵ m (femtometres), roughly the size of a nucleus.

distractorExplanations.Infinite distance: Unlike electrostatic force, the strong force has a very limited range.
distractorExplanations.About 10⁻¹⁰ m: This is atomic scale; the strong force acts at nuclear scale (10⁻¹⁵ m).
distractorExplanations.About 1 m: This is macroscopic scale, far beyond the strong force's range.

toLevel2.question: What is the primary role of the strong nuclear force in the nucleus?
options: To overcome electrostatic repulsion and hold nucleons together
To attract electrons to the nucleus
toLevel2.correct: To overcome electrostatic repulsion and hold nucleons together
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force binds nucleons together, overcoming the repulsion between protons to keep the nucleus stable.

distractorExplanations.To push protons apart: The strong force attracts, not repels. Electrostatic force pushes protons apart.
distractorExplanations.To attract electrons to the nucleus: Electrons are bound by electrostatic force, not the strong force.
distractorExplanations.To create radioactive decay: The strong force stabilises nuclei; decay occurs when stability is lost.

toLevel2.question: The strong nuclear force is {{c1::attractive}} and acts between all nucleons.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force pulls nucleons together, providing the binding that holds the nucleus intact.

toLevel2.question: The strong nuclear force is about {{c1::100}} times stronger than the electrostatic force at nuclear distances.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: This significant strength advantage allows it to overcome proton-proton repulsion within the nucleus.

toLevel2.question: The strong force only acts over very {{c1::short}} distances of about 10⁻¹⁵ m.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: This short range is why the strong force doesn't affect particles outside the nucleus.

toLevel2.question: The strong nuclear force acts between protons and electrons.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force acts between nucleons (protons and neutrons) only. Electrons do not experience the strong force.

toLevel2.question: The strong nuclear force has a much shorter range than the electrostatic force.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong force only acts at nuclear distances (~10⁻¹⁵ m), while electrostatic force acts over infinite range.

toLevel3.question: Why does the strong force overcome electrostatic repulsion inside the nucleus?
options: At nuclear distances, the strong force is stronger than electrostatic repulsion
Protons have no charge inside the nucleus
The nucleus is too small for electrostatic forces
toLevel3.correct: At nuclear distances, the strong force is stronger than electrostatic repulsion
toLevel3.correctExplanation: When nucleons are within about 10⁻¹⁵ m of each other, the strong attractive force exceeds the electrostatic repulsion.

distractorExplanations.Protons have no charge inside the nucleu: Protons always retain their positive charge.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons cancel out proton charges: Neutrons are neutral and don't cancel charges; they contribute to the strong force.
distractorExplanations.The nucleus is too small for electrostat: Electrostatic forces act at all scales; they are present but overcome by the strong force.

toLevel3.question: Why does the short range of the strong force explain nuclear instability in very large nuclei?
options: Nucleons on opposite sides of a large nucleus don't attract each other strongly
Large nuclei have too many electrons
The strong force becomes weaker in large nuclei
toLevel3.correct: Nucleons on opposite sides of a large nucleus don't attract each other strongly
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The strong force only acts on nearby nucleons. In large nuclei, distant protons repel each other without compensating strong force attraction.

distractorExplanations.Large nuclei have too many electrons: Electrons don't affect nuclear stability directly.
distractorExplanations.The strong force becomes weaker in large: The force itself doesn't weaken; it just can't reach distant nucleons.
distractorExplanations.Large nuclei have no neutrons: Large nuclei have many neutrons, but they can't overcome long-range electrostatic repulsion.

toLevel3.question: Why is it important that the strong force acts between neutrons as well as protons?
options: Neutrons contribute to binding without adding electrostatic repulsion
Neutrons are only found in small nuclei
toLevel3.correct: Neutrons contribute to binding without adding electrostatic repulsion
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Neutrons experience the strong force but have no charge, so they add binding strength without increasing repulsion.

distractorExplanations.Neutrons are heavier than protons: While slightly heavier, this doesn't explain their role in nuclear binding.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons are only found in small nuclei: All nuclei except hydrogen-1 contain neutrons.

toLevel3.question: What happens to the strong force when two nucleons are separated beyond nuclear distances?
options: It continues at the same strength
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The strong force has extremely short range. Beyond about 10⁻¹⁵ m, it becomes negligible.

distractorExplanations.It continues at the same strength: Unlike electrostatic force, the strong force has limited range.
distractorExplanations.It becomes repulsive: The strong force doesn't become repulsive; it simply drops off.
distractorExplanations.It converts to electrostatic force: These are fundamentally different forces; one doesn't convert to the other.

toLevel3.question: In a helium-4 nucleus, how does the strong force maintain stability?
options: Each nucleon attracts its neighbours, overcoming proton-proton repulsion
There is no electrostatic repulsion in helium
The nucleus is too small for forces to act
toLevel3.correct: Each nucleon attracts its neighbours, overcoming proton-proton repulsion
toLevel3.correctExplanation: All four nucleons are close enough for strong force attraction, which exceeds the repulsion between the two protons.

distractorExplanations.There is no electrostatic repulsion in h: The two protons definitely repel each other.
distractorExplanations.The nucleus is too small for forces to a: Forces act at all scales; small nuclei have strong force binding.
distractorExplanations.Electrons shield the protons: Electrons orbit outside the nucleus and don't affect nuclear forces.

toLevel3.question: The strong force is {{c1::short-range}} compared to the electrostatic force, which acts over infinite distances.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: This fundamental difference means the strong force only binds nearby nucleons, while electrostatic repulsion acts across the entire nucleus.

toLevel3.question: Neutrons help stabilise nuclei because they experience the strong force without adding {{c1::electrostatic repulsion}}.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Being neutral, neutrons contribute binding through the strong force but don't increase the repulsion between charged protons.

toLevel3.question: In very large nuclei, protons on opposite sides experience electrostatic repulsion but little {{c1::strong force}} attraction.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The strong force's short range means it can't reach across a large nucleus, while electrostatic repulsion has infinite range.

toLevel3.question: The strong force acts equally between proton-proton, neutron-neutron, and proton-neutron pairs.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The strong force is charge-independent and acts between all types of nucleon pairs with similar strength.

toLevel3.question: Beyond the range of the strong force, nucleons continue to attract each other through other means.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Beyond strong force range, there is no significant attractive force between nucleons. Only electrostatic repulsion (between protons) remains.

toLevel4.question: A nucleon in the centre of a large nucleus experiences strong force from how many other nucleons?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Due to the short range of the strong force (~10⁻¹⁵ m), each nucleon only interacts strongly with nucleons immediately adjacent to it.

distractorExplanations.All nucleons in the nucleus: The strong force doesn't reach across the entire nucleus.
distractorExplanations.No nucleons: Nucleons within range definitely experience the strong force.
distractorExplanations.Only protons: The strong force acts on all nucleons, not just protons.

toLevel4.question: If the strong force had infinite range like electrostatic force, what would happen to nuclear stability?
options: All nuclei would be extremely stable regardless of size
toLevel4.correct: All nuclei would be extremely stable regardless of size
toLevel4.correctExplanation: If the strong force could act across the entire nucleus, it would easily overcome electrostatic repulsion at any nuclear size.

distractorExplanations.All nuclei would be unstable: An infinite-range strong force would provide more binding, not less.
distractorExplanations.Nothing would change: The limited range is crucial to understanding nuclear stability limits.
distractorExplanations.Only small nuclei would exist: Unlimited strong force range would stabilise large nuclei.

toLevel4.question: Uranium-238 has 92 protons spread across a nucleus about 15 fm in diameter. Why is the strong force insufficient to fully stabilise it?
options: Protons across the nucleus repel each other, but the strong force only reaches nearby nucleons
The strong force is weaker in uranium
Uranium nuclei are too small for forces to act
toLevel4.correct: Protons across the nucleus repel each other, but the strong force only reaches nearby nucleons
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At 15 fm diameter, many protons are beyond strong force range of each other, so electrostatic repulsion isn't fully compensated.

distractorExplanations.Uranium has no neutrons: U-238 has 146 neutrons, but even these can't fully overcome the large electrostatic repulsion.
distractorExplanations.The strong force is weaker in uranium: The strong force has the same strength per nucleon; it's the range that limits it.
distractorExplanations.Uranium nuclei are too small for forces: Uranium nuclei are relatively large at ~15 fm diameter.

toLevel4.question: The nuclear binding energy per nucleon peaks around iron (A~56). What does this tell us about the balance of forces?
options: Medium-sized nuclei have optimal balance between strong force binding and electrostatic repulsion
The strong force only works in iron
Electrostatic force doesn't exist in iron
toLevel4.correct: Medium-sized nuclei have optimal balance between strong force binding and electrostatic repulsion
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In medium nuclei, nucleons are close enough for strong force binding while electrostatic repulsion hasn't become overwhelming.

distractorExplanations.Iron has special nuclear properties: Iron follows the same physics; it just happens to be at the optimal size.
distractorExplanations.The strong force only works in iron: The strong force acts in all nuclei.
distractorExplanations.Electrostatic force doesn't exist in iro: Electrostatic repulsion exists in all nuclei with protons.

toLevel4.question: When an alpha particle is emitted from a large nucleus, why does the daughter nucleus become more stable?
options: Removing nucleons reduces electrostatic repulsion while strong force binding per nucleon remains similar
Alpha particles carry away all instability
toLevel4.correct: Removing nucleons reduces electrostatic repulsion while strong force binding per nucleon remains similar
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Removing 2 protons significantly reduces repulsion, while the strong force still binds the remaining nucleons similarly.

distractorExplanations.Alpha particles carry away all instabili: Stability improves due to changed force balance, not removal of 'instability'.
distractorExplanations.The daughter has no protons: The daughter still has many protons, just fewer than the parent.
distractorExplanations.Strong force increases after emission: The strong force per nucleon stays roughly constant; it's the repulsion that decreases.

toLevel4.question: In a large nucleus, a nucleon interacts via strong force with approximately {{c1::12}} nearest neighbours.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In a closely-packed nuclear structure, each nucleon has about 12 nearest neighbours within strong force range.

toLevel4.question: The binding energy per nucleon peaks at nuclei around iron because this size optimises the balance between {{c1::strong force and electrostatic repulsion}}.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Medium nuclei achieve maximum binding because strong force binding is efficient while electrostatic repulsion is manageable.

toLevel4.question: The strong force has a range of approximately {{c1::1-3}} femtometres, after which it becomes negligible.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The strong force is significant up to about 1-3 fm, corresponding to the distance between adjacent nucleons.

toLevel4.question: A proton at the surface of a large nucleus experiences strong force attraction from protons on the opposite side.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The strong force range is only about 1-3 fm. In a large nucleus (10+ fm diameter), opposite sides are too far apart.

toLevel4.question: The saturation of nuclear binding energy (roughly constant binding per nucleon) is evidence of the short range of the strong force.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: If strong force had infinite range, binding energy would increase with A². The observed near-constant value per nucleon indicates each nucleon only binds to nearby neighbours.

toLevel5.question: The residual strong force between nucleons is itself a secondary effect of the fundamental strong force between quarks. What does this imply about the complexity of nuclear binding?
options: Nuclear binding involves complex multi-body quantum chromodynamic effects
The strong force is simple and well understood
Nuclear physics can ignore quark-level physics
toLevel5.correct: Nuclear binding involves complex multi-body quantum chromodynamic effects
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The nuclear strong force is the residual effect of quark-gluon interactions, making nuclear binding a complex quantum phenomenon.

distractorExplanations.The strong force is simple and well unde: While effective models exist, the underlying physics involves complex QCD.
distractorExplanations.Quarks don't exist in nucleons: Protons and neutrons are composed of quarks.
distractorExplanations.Nuclear physics can ignore quark-level p: Quark physics underlies nuclear forces, though effective theories often work well.

toLevel5.question: The Yukawa potential describes the strong force as mediated by virtual meson exchange. How does this explain the short range?
options: Massive exchange particles limit the range according to the uncertainty principle
The range is determined by proton mass
Virtual particles have no effect on range
toLevel5.correct: Massive exchange particles limit the range according to the uncertainty principle
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The uncertainty principle limits how far massive virtual particles can travel before being reabsorbed, giving the force a finite range of ~1-2 fm.

distractorExplanations.Mesons travel at infinite speed: Virtual particles still obey quantum mechanical constraints.
distractorExplanations.The range is determined by proton mass: The range depends on the mass of the exchange particle (pion), not the proton.
distractorExplanations.Virtual particles have no effect on rang: Virtual particle mass directly determines force range.

toLevel5.question: In the nuclear shell model, magic numbers represent particularly stable nuclei. How do these relate to the strong force?
options: Filled nuclear shells represent optimal arrangements of nucleons under strong force binding
Magic numbers ignore the strong force
Only electrostatic effects create magic numbers
toLevel5.correct: Filled nuclear shells represent optimal arrangements of nucleons under strong force binding
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Magic numbers arise from quantum mechanics of nucleons in the strong force potential well, similar to electron shells in atoms.

distractorExplanations.Magic numbers ignore the strong force: Magic numbers emerge directly from strong force binding effects.
distractorExplanations.Only electrostatic effects create magic: The shell structure is primarily determined by the strong force potential.
distractorExplanations.Magic numbers are purely coincidental: They have deep quantum mechanical origins in nuclear structure.

toLevel5.question: The tensor component of the nuclear force causes the deuteron to have a non-spherical shape. What does this reveal about the strong force?
options: The strong force has orientation-dependent components beyond simple attraction
toLevel5.correct: The strong force has orientation-dependent components beyond simple attraction
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The tensor force creates a preferred alignment between nucleon spins and their relative position, deforming the deuteron.

distractorExplanations.All nuclei are perfectly spherical: Many nuclei, including the deuteron, are deformed.
distractorExplanations.The strong force is isotropic: The tensor component shows the force depends on spin-orbit orientation.
distractorExplanations.Deuterons have no structure: The deuteron has measurable quadrupole moment due to its structure.

toLevel5.question: Nuclear forces become repulsive at extremely short distances (< 0.5 fm). How does this affect nuclear structure?
options: It prevents nucleons from collapsing into a point and maintains constant nuclear density
It causes all nuclei to be unstable
It makes the strong force weaker overall
toLevel5.correct: It prevents nucleons from collapsing into a point and maintains constant nuclear density
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The repulsive core prevents unlimited compression, explaining why nuclear density is roughly constant across all stable nuclei.

distractorExplanations.It causes all nuclei to be unstable: The repulsive core actually contributes to stability by preventing collapse.
distractorExplanations.It makes the strong force weaker overall: The attractive part is still dominant at normal nuclear distances.
distractorExplanations.It only affects electrons: Electrons don't experience the strong force at all.

toLevel5.question: The pion mass of approximately 140 MeV/c² corresponds to a strong force range of about {{c1::1.4}} femtometres via the uncertainty principle.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Using ΔE·Δt ≈ ℏ and E = mc², the range r ≈ ℏc/(mc²) ≈ 197 MeV·fm / 140 MeV ≈ 1.4 fm.

toLevel5.question: The {{c1::repulsive core}} of the nuclear force at very short distances prevents nucleons from overlapping completely.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Below about 0.5 fm, the nuclear force becomes strongly repulsive, creating the hard core that limits nuclear compression.

toLevel5.question: The strong force between nucleons is actually the {{c1::residual}} effect of the fundamental strong force between quarks mediated by gluons.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Similar to how van der Waals forces are residual electromagnetic effects, nuclear forces are residual QCD effects.

toLevel5.question: The strong force between nucleons can be exactly calculated from first principles using QCD.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: QCD calculations at nuclear scales are extremely difficult. Effective theories and models are typically used instead.

toLevel5.question: The fact that nuclear density is approximately constant regardless of nuclear size is evidence for the saturation property of the strong force.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Saturation (each nucleon binds only to neighbours) plus the repulsive core explains why adding nucleons increases volume proportionally.
